description.p: The following examples illustrate the present invention without, however, limiting the same thereto.

heading.b: EXAMPLE 1: Protocol for identifying functional orthologs in other species

description.p: To identify orthologous genes, the following procedure was used: The identified homologous amino acid sequences themselves were used for BLAST searches. If the original C. elegans protein was (re-)identified by a BLAST hit with an e-value of less than 10-5, the identified homolog was defined as an ortholog. The BLAST search was performed with the default parameters and the low complexity filter on. An alternative parameter for identification of homologous genes can be the percentage of sequence identity. Over 100 residues, a sequence identity of 30% defines a homologous gene. After the BLAST search is completed, multiple sequence alignment is performed using appropriate software (for example, CLUSTALW) and a neighbour joining phylogenetic tree is generated. Any person skilled in the art can identify the human ortholog from a phylogenetic tree. Essentially, the human sequence that is separated on the tree by a single speciation event or most closely related on the tree is likely to be an ortholog.

heading.b: EXAMPLE 2: Generation of dsRNA molecules for RNAi experiments

description.p: First, oligonucleotide primer pair sequences were selected to amplify portions of the gene of interest's coding region using standard PCR techniques. Primer pairs were chosen to yield PCR products containing at least 500 bases of coding sequence, or a maximum of coding bases for genes smaller than 500 bases. In order to permit the subsequent use of the PCR product as a template for in vitro RNA transcription reactions from both DNA strands, the T7 polymerase promoter sequence "TAATACGACTCACTATAGG" was added to the 5' end of forward primers, and the T3 polymerase promoter sequence "AATTAACCCTCACTAAAGG" was added to the 5' end of reverse primers. The synthesis of oligonucleotide primers was completed by a commercial supplier (Sigma-Genosys, UK or MWG-Biotech, Germany).

PCR reactions were performed in a volume of 50 µl, with Taq polymerase using 0.8 µM primers and approximately 0.1 µg of wild-type (N2 strain) genomic DNA template. The PCR products were EtOH precipitated, washed with 70% EtOH and resuspended in 7.0 µl TE. 1.0 µl of the PCR reaction was pipetted into each of two fresh tubes for 5 µl transcription reactions using T3 and T7 RNA polymerases. The separate T3 and T7 transcription reactions were performed according to the manufacturer's instructions (Ambion, Megascript kit), each diluted to 50 µl with RNase-free water and then combined. The mixed RNA was purified using RNeasy kits according to the manufacturer's instructions (Qiagen), and eluted into a total of 130 µl of RNase-free H2O. 50 µl of this was mixed with 10 µl 6X injection buffer (40 mM KPO4 pH 7.5, 6 mM potassium citrate, pH 7,5, 4% PEG 6000). The RNA was annealed by heating at 68°C for 10 min, and at 37°C for 30 min. Concentration of the final dsRNAs were measured to be in the range of 0.1-0.3 µg/µl. The products of the PCR reaction, of the T3 and T7 transcription reactions, as well as the dsRNA species were run on 1% agarose gels to be examined for quality control purposes. Success of double stranding was assessed by scoring shift in gel mobility with respect to single stranded RNA, when run on non-denaturing gels.

heading.b: EXAMPLE 3: Injections of dsRNA and phenotypic assays

description.p: dsRNAs were injected bilaterally into the syncytial portion of both gonads of wild-type (N2 strain) young adult hermaphrodites, and the animals incubated at 20°C for 24 hrs. Embryos were then dissected out from the injected animals and analyzed by time-lapse differential interference contrast videomicroscopy for potential defects in cell division processes, capturing 1 image every 5 seconds, as previously described (Gönczy et al., Dissection of cell division processes in the one cell stage Caenorhabditis elegans embryo by mutational analysis. J Cell Biol 144, 927-946 (1999)). For each experiment, embryos from at least 3 different injected worms were filmed in this manner, from shortly after fertilization until the four cell stage. Embryos from 2 additional injected worms were recorded for shorter periods, covering the 2 cell and the 4 cell stage, respectively, thus yielding documentation for at least 5 injected worms in each experiment.

In some cases, embryos exhibited acute sensitivity to osmotic changes, as evidenced by their loss of structural integrity during the dissection of the injected animals. In order to overcome this limitation, injected animals were not dissected, but rather, anaesthetized for 10 min in M9 medium containing 0.1 % tricaine and 0.01 % tetramisole, and mounted intact on an agarose pad to observe the F1 embryogenesis in utero (Kirby et al., Dev. Biol. 142, 203-215 (1990)). The resolution achieved by viewing through the body wall does not equal that achieved by observing dissected embryos, and only limited phenotypic analysis was conducted in these cases.

Three injected worms were also transferred to 3 fresh plates 24 hrs after injection of the dsRNA, and left at 18°C. Three days later, the plates were checked with a stereomicroscope (20-40x total magnification) for the presence of F1 larvae (L2's - L4's), as well as their developmental stage. Three days after that, the plates were inspected again for the presence of F1 adults, as well as their overall body morphology and the presence of F2 progeny.

heading.b: EXAMPLE 4: Characterization of the C. elegans gene F59E12.11

description.p: dsRNA was designed and used to specifically silence the expression of the C. elegans gene by RNAi, thereby testing its functional involvement in the first round of embryonic cell division in this metazoan species. The dsRNA was synthesized in vitro from PCR-amplified wild type genomic DNA fragments of the F59E12.11 gene. For PCR, the following primer pair was used: "TAATACGACTCACTATAGGGGATTTCTTCAATCGGCTCA" with "AATTAACCCTCACTAAAGGTATGTCGTTCGTCCCATCAG" as forward and reverse primers, respectively. The dsRNA was purified, and injected into adult hermaphrodite worms. The phenotypic consequences of the RNAi treatment were documented 24 hours later in the F1 progeny of injected worms, using time-lapse differential interference contrast (DIC) microscopy. Embryo recordings started ~20 minutes after fertilisation, while the female pronucleus is completing its meiotic divisions, until ~15 to 20 minutes later.

Control worms were either not injected, or injected with irrelevant dsRNA. Irrelevant dsRNA was made of the same nucleotide composition as the experimental dsRNA, but the nucleotides were in random order. In the F1 progeny of such control worms the cellular events of the first two rounds of embryonic cell division were found to exhibit very limited variability, as observed by DIC microscopy. All processes that were examined and scored for the possibility of phenotypic deviations are listed and illustrated in Figure 5. Briefly, the antero-posterior polarity of the embryo is initially determined by the position of the male pronucleus at the cortex, shortly after entry into the egg. This is accompanied by a clear, coordinated flow of yolk granules through the central portion of the cytoplasm along the embryo's longitudinal axis towards the male pronucleus, and a concomitant series of cortical waves or ruffles progressing towards the anterior of the embryo. Shortly thereafter, the male and female pronuclei undergo highly patterned migrations resulting in their meeting within the posterior half of the embryo, followed by a centration and rotation of the pronuclear pair and associated centrosomes to set up the future mitotic spindle along the embryo's longitudinal axis. After synchronous breakdown of the pronuclear envelopes, the clearly bipolar mitotic spindle is initially short, but then rockingly elongates. These movements are accompanied by a slight posterior displacement of the posterior spindle pole, while the anterior spindle pole remains approximately stationary. This then results in an asymmetric positioning of the spindle during anaphase and telophase, thereby yielding an asymmetric placement of the cytokinetic furrow, and generating unequally-sized daughter cells: a smaller posterior P1 blastomere, and larger anterior AB blastomere. While the AB nucleus then migrates directly to the center of the AB cell, the P1 nucleus typically migrates further towards the posterior of that cell, before undergoing a pronounced 90° rotation while re-migrating to the anterior P1 cortex with one of its duplicated centrosomes leading. This insures that the P1 blastomere then divides along the embryo's longitudinal axis, perpendicular to that of the AB blastomere. These two divisions occur asynchronously, with P1 lagging 2-3 minutes behind AB.

In the F1 embryos of worms injected with dsRNA, the following highly reproducible phenotypes are observed (Fig. 1). The embryos show an irregular cytoplasmic texture. At the poles, areas of uncondensed chromosomal material can be observed (arrows). The embryos arrest development before pronuclear formation. The phenotype is accompanied by osmotic instability, which presented itself by the embryo filling the egg shell. The phenotype is embryonic lethal.

All observed phenotypes indicate a requirement for F59E12.11 gene function in cell cycle progression during mitosis. Since this function is essential to cell division throughout metazoans, this gene and any homologs and derivatives thereof represent excellent tools for use in the development of a wide range of therapeutics including anti-proliferative agents. Analysis of the F59E12.11 gene sequence reveals a clear ortholog in human (GenBank Accession No. NP_477517), the sequence similarity being in the N-terminal half of the protein. The ortholog had no function ascribed to it until now. There has been no information linking the genes to cell cycle control or cell cycle progression. Based on the extremely high sequence conservation at the protein level, it can be concluded that the ortholog most likely encodes a protein with equivalent function in cell cycle progression in humans.

heading.b: EXAMPLE 5: Characterization of the C. elegans gene Y71H2B.3

description.p: dsRNA was designed and used to specifically silence the expression of the C. elegans gene by RNAi, thereby testing its functional involvement in the first 2 rounds of embryonic cell division in this metazoan species. The dsRNA was synthesized in vitro from PCR-amplified wild type genomic DNA fragments of Y71H2B.3. For PCR, the following primer pair was used: "TAATACGACTCACTATAGGTGCGAAACCTGAATTTTTCC" with "AATTAACCCTCACTAAAGGGCTCATCAATTGAAACGGCT" as forward and reverse primers, respectively. The dsRNA was purified, and injected into adult hermaphrodite worms. The phenotypic consequences of the RNAi treatment were documented 24 hours later in the F1 progeny of injected worms, using time-lapse differential interference contrast (DIC) microscopy. Embryo recordings started ~20 minutes after fertilisation, while the female pronucleus is completing its meiotic divisions, until the 4 cell stage, ~30 minutes later.

In the F1 progeny of control worms that were either not injected, or injected with irrelevant dsRNA, the cellular events of the first two rounds of embryonic cell division were found to exhibit very limited variability, as observed by DIC microscopy and described in Example 3.

In the F1 embryos of worms injected with dsRNA, the following highly reproducible phenotypes are observed (Fig. 3). There is a lack of cortical ruffling (symbolized by the cross in Fig. 3 A) with some irregular blebbing at the anterior end of the embryo, resulting in attenuated furrowing at the pseudo-cleavage stage (Fig. 3 B, white arrow). Pronuclei are small and irregular in shape (Fig. 3 B and C, black arrows). Pronuclei meet but are not centred, the mitotic spindle is set up at the posterior end of the embryo. The spindle is short, poorly visible and lacks spindle rocking (Fig. 3 E), resulting in chromosome segregation defects (Fig. 3 F and G). At the two-cell stage irregular cortical blebbing was observed (Fig. 3 G, arrows). The P1 cell divides significantly later than normal (Fig. 3 H, arrow).

All observed phenotypes indicate a requirement for Y71H2B.3 gene function in gene function in cell cycle progression during cell division. Since this function is essential to cell division throughout metazoans, this gene and any homologs and derivatives thereof represent excellent tools for use in the development of a wide range of therapeutics including anti-proliferative agents. Analysis of the Y71H2B.3 gene sequence has revealed orthologs in human (GenBank Accession No. NP_001542), rat (GenBank Accession No. AAD05364 or NP_113812), Drosophila (GenBank Accession No. AAF53289), and Saccharomyces cerevisiae (GenBank Accession No. NP_013741). The identified ortholog is immunoglobulin-binding protein 1, which is involved in IgR-mediated signal transduction in B-cells. There has been no information regarding Y71H2B.3 or these orthologs having a role in cell cycle progression or cell division.

heading.b: EXAMPLE 6: Effects of RNA; treatment in human cells

description.p: For all experiments in human cells short double stranded interfering RNAs (siRNAs) of 21 bases in length, comprised of a 19 bp core of complementary sequence and 2 bases overhang at the 3' end, were designed by Cenix and chemically synthesized by Ambion Inc., Austin, Texas, USA.

The following siRNA sequences were used:
scrambled negative control
positive control (PCNA, proliferating cell nuclear antigen)
NP_477517.1
NP_001542.1

HeLa cells were treated with siRNAs at a final concentration of 100nM using a lipofection based transfection protocol. 24 h before transfection, HeLa cells were seeded in 96well plates at a density of 6,000 cells/well.
On the day of transfection, the transfection mix was prepared as follow: 1 µl of a 10 µM stock of siRNA was diluted with 16 µl of Opti-MEM (Invitrogen Inc.), and 0.4 µl Oligofectamine transfection reagent (Invitrogen) were diluted with 2.4 µl of Opti-MEM. For complex formation, both solutions were gently mixed and incubated for 20 min at RT. Culture medium was removed from the cells and 80 µl of fresh medium (DMEM, Invitrogen) were added, followed by addition of 20 µl of transfection mix. Cells were incubated at 37°C for 4 hours, 50 µl of fresh medium, supplemented with 30 % fetal calf serum were added, followed by another incubation for 48-72 hours.

heading.i: Determination of silencing level by quantitative RT-PCR (qRT-PCR)

description.p: 48 hours after transfection, total RNA was extracted from RNAi treated cells using Invisorb kits (Invitek GmbH, Berlin), and cDNA was produced with ABI TaqMan reverse transcription reagents (Applied Biosystems, USA). In both cases the manufacturer's instructions were followed. Quantitative real-time PCR was performed using the following protocol: 5.5µl of 2x SybrGreen PCR mix (Applied Biosystems) were mixed with 3 µl of sample cDNA and 2.5 µl of a 2 µM solution of gene specific PCR primers, followed by incubation in a ABI-7900-HT real-time PCR machine at 50°C 2min - 95°C 10min - 45 cycles (95°C 15sec - 60°C 1min) - 95°C 15sec - 60°C 15sec - 95°C 15sec. In addition to the gene specific reaction, a second, reference reaction was run for each cDNA sample, using primers for 18S rRNA. Amplification signals from different gene specific samples were normalized using the reference values on 18S rRNA for these respective samples, and compared to samples from control (scrambled siRNA from Ambion Inc.) treated cells.

In order to quantify the number of living cells after RNAi treatment, ATP levels were measured 72h after transfection using the ATPlite assay (Perkin Elmer). Cells were extracted and treated according to the manufacturer's instructions. Luminescence read out was performed on a Victor 2 multi label reader (Perkin Elmer). For graphical presentation purposes the proliferation of untreated cells was set to 100.

The levels of programmed cell death in RNAi treated cells were determined 72 hours after transfection, using the Caspase 3/7 specific fluorometric assay ApoOne by Promega, following the manufacturer's instructions. Read out was performed on a Victor 2 multi label reader (Perkin Elmer). For graphical presentation purposes the apoptosis rate of untreated cells was set to 100.

Phosphorylation at serin 10 of histone H3 is considered a hallmark of mitosis, appearing in early prophase and disappearing during telophase. Using immunofluorescence microscopy, mitotic cells can be revealed by an increased binding of a phospho-histone H3 antibody, detected by a suitable fluorescence labelled secondary antibody.

RNAi treated cells in 96 well microscopy plates were stained using the following protocol: Cells were washed with PBS and fixed with 4% para-formaldehyde for 30 min at RT, followed by three washes with PBS. Cells were then permeabilised and blocked in the presence of 0.1 % Triton X-100 and 2% BSA for 30 min. The supernatant was removed and anti Phospho Histone H3 (mouse monoclonal antibody clone 6G3, Cell Signalling Technologies) was added at a dilution of 1:750 for 2 hours at RT, followed by three washes with PBS. For detection of Phosph Histone H3 labelled nuclei, goat anti mouse antibody (1:500), coupled to Alexa Fluor 568 (Molecular Probes) was added in a solution supplemented with 0.5 µg/ml Dapi (4',6-diamidino-2-phenylindole, dihydrochloride), FluoroPure™ grade, Molecular Probes) for detection of all nuclei. After incubation for 2 hours at RT, cells were washed four times and images were taken using an automated microscopy system (Discovery-1, Universal Imaging Inc.), acquiring a minimum of 6 images/well. Metamorph-HCS image processing software was used to determine the numbers of mitotic and overall nuclei. The Mitotic Index resembles the fraction of mitotic over all nuclei in a given cell population. For graphical presentation purposes the MI of untreated cells was set to 100.

RNAi treatment of HeLa cells using an siRNA directed against NP_477517.1, the human ortholog of C. elegans gene F59E12.11, results in a 40% reduction of cell proliferation and a 2fold increase in the rate of apoptosis.RNAi treatment of HeLa cells using an siRNA directed against NP_001542.1, the human ortholog of C. elegans gene Y71H2B.3, results in a 80% reduction of cell proliferation, a 2.5fold increase in the rate of apoptosis, and a significant drop in the mitotic index.
description.heading: SEQUENCE LISTING

ul.li: <120> The use of eukaryotic genes affecting cell cycle control or cell cycle progression for diagnosis and treatment of proliferative diseases

claim.claim-text: Isoliertes Nukleinsäuremolekül umfassend ein Nukleinsäuremolekül mit einer Sequenz ausgewählt aus der Gruppe bestehend aus: a) Sequenzen von Nukleinsäuremolekülen, die unter mittel- oder hochstringenten Bedingungen in der Lage sind, zu hybridisieren mit - den Nukleinsäuremolekülen mit den Sequenzen, die in SEQ ID Nr: 1, 3 dargestellt sind, oder - Nukleinsäuresequenzen, die Polypeptide kodieren, die mit dem Protein, das von einer Nukleinsäure gemäß SEQ ID Nr: 1 oder 3 kodiert wird, eine Sequenzidentität von mindestens 70 % über 100 Reste zeigen und/oder die in einer computergestützten Suche unter Verwendung der BLAST Sequenzanalyseprogramme mit einem e-Wert von höchstens 10-5 auffindbar sind, b) der Antisense-Sequenz einer beliebigen der wie in SEQ ID Nr: 1, 3 definierten Sequenzen oder der Antisense-Sequenz einer beliebigen der Nukleinsäuresequenzen, die Polypeptide kodieren, die mit dem Protein, das von einer Nukleinsäure gemäß SEQ ID Nr: 1 oder 3 kodiert wird, eine Sequenzidentität von mindestens 70 % über 100 Reste zeigen und/oder die in einer computergestützten Suche unter Verwendung der BLAST Sequenzanalyseprogramme mit einem e-Wert von höchstens 10-5 auffindbar sind, c) Fragmente von (a) oder (b), wobei die Fragmente größer als 15 Nukleotide sind, d) einzelsträngige RNA in Antisense-Richtung entsprechend einer beliebigen der wie in SEQ ID Nr: 1, 3 definierten Sequenzen oder entsprechend einer beliebigen der Nukleinsäuresequenzen, die Polypeptide kodieren, die mit dem Protein, das von einer Nukleinsäure gemäß SEQ ID Nr: 1 oder 3 kodiert wird, eine Sequenzidentität von mindestens 70 % über 100 Reste zeigen und/oder die in einer computergestützten Suche unter Verwendung der BLAST Sequenzanalyseprogramme mit einem e-Wert von höchstens 10-5 auffindbar sind, oder einzelsträngige RNA in Sense-Richtung entsprechend einer beliebigen der wie in (a) definierten Sequenzen zur Verwendung in einem Verfahren zur Therapie einer proliferativen Erkrankung durch Inhibierung des Fortschreitens des Zellzyklus.

Nukleinsäuremolekül zur Verwendung gemäß Anspruch 1, wobei das isolierte Nukleinsäuremolekül kleine interferierende RNA mit einer Sequenz entsprechend einer der beliebigen der Sequenzen nach Anspruch 1 umfasst oder wobei das Nukleinsäuremolekül in mindestens einem Nukleinsäure-Expressionsvektor enthalten ist, der in der Lage ist, ein doppelsträngiges RNA-Molekül unter geeigneten Bedingungen herzustellen, das einen Sense-RNA-Strang und einen Antisense-RNA-Strang umfasst, wobei jeder RNA-Strang unabhängig voneinander eine Länge von 19 bis 31 Nukleotiden aufweist.

Nukleinsäuremolekül zur Verwendung gemäß Anspruch 1, wobei das Nukleinsäuremolekül in mindestens einem Nukleinsäure-Expressionsvektor enthalten ist, der eine erste Expressionskassette, die die Nukleinsäure entsprechend dem Sense-RNA-Strang unter Kontrolle eines ersten Promotors enthält, und eine zweite Expressionskassette, die die Nukleinsäure entsprechend dem Antisense-RNA-Strang unter der Kontrolle eines zweiten Promotors enthält, umfasst.

Nukleinsäuremolekül zur Verwendung gemäß Anspruch 1, wobei des Nukleinsäuremolekül in mindestens einem Nukleinsäure-Expressionsvektor enthalten ist, der eine Expressionskassette, die die Nukleinsäure entsprechend dem Sense-RNA-Strang und dem Antisense-RNA-Strang unter der Kontrolle eines Promotors enthält, was zu einem einzelsträngigen RNA-Molekül führt, und wobei das einzelsträngige RNA-Molekül zur Bildung einer zurückgefalteten Haarnadelstruktur in der Lage ist.

Nukleinsäuremolekül zur Verwendung gemäß einem beliebigen der Ansprüche 2 bis 4, wobei jeder RNA-Strang unabhängig voneinander eine Länge von 20 bis 25, vorzugsweise von 20 bis 22 Nukleotiden aufweist.
Nukleinsäuremolekül zur Verwendung gemäß einem beliebigen der Ansprüche 2 bis 4, wobei jeder RNA-Strang unabhängig voneinander eine Länge von 26 bis 28, vorzugsweise 27 Nukleotiden aufweist.

Antikörper, der gerichtet ist gegen mindestens ein Peptid oder Polypeptid mit einer Sequenz ausgewählt aus der Gruppe bestehend aus: a) einer Sequenz wie in SEQ ID Nr: 2, 4 offenbart; b) einer Sequenz, die mit einer beliebigen der Sequenzen gemäß a) eine Sequenzidentität von mindestens 70 % über 100 Reste aufweist, c) Fragmente der wie in a) oder b) definierten Sequenzen, wobei die Fragmente von Fragmenten von Nukleinsäuresequenzen, die länger als 15 Nukleotide sind, kodiert werden zur Verwendung in einem Verfahren zur Therapie einer proliferativen Erkrankung durch Inhibieren des Fortschreitens des Zellzyklus.

Nukleinsäuremolekül zur Verwendung gemäß einem beliebigen der Ansprüche 1 bis 6 oder Antikörper zur Verwendung gemäß Anspruch 7, wobei die Erkrankung koronare Restenose oder eine neoplastische Erkrankung ist, wobei letztere ausgewählt ist aus der Gruppe bestehend aus Lymphom, Lungenkrebs, Kolonkrebs, Eierstockkrebs und Brustkrebs.

Arzneimittel enthaltend ein Nukleinsäuremolekül enthaltend eine Nukleinsäure mit einer Sequenz ausgewählt aus der Gruppe von Sequenzen bestehend aus: a) die Nukleinsäuresequenzen dargestellt in SEQ ID Nr: 1, 3; b) Nukleinsäuresequenzen kodierend Polypeptide, die mit dem Protein, das von einer Nukleinsäure gemäß a) kodiert wird, eine Sequenzidentität von mindestens 70 % über 100 Reste zeigen und/oder die in einer computergestützten Suche unter Verwendung der BLAST Sequenzanalyseprogramme mit einem e-Wert von höchstens 10-5 auffindbar sind, c) Fragmente von (a) oder (b), wobei die Fragmente größer als 15 Nukleotide sind, oder ein isoliertes Peptid oder Polypeptid umfassend ein Peptid oder Polypeptid mit einer Sequenz ausgewählt aus der Gruppe bestehend aus: d) einer Sequenz wie in SEQ ID Nr: 2, 4 offenbart, e) einer Sequenz, die mit einer beliebigen der Sequenzen gemäß d) eine Sequenzidentität von mindestens 70 % über 100 Reste aufweist, f) Fragmente der wie in d) oder e) definierten Sequenzen, wobei die Fragmente von Fragmenten von Nukleinsäuresequenzen, die länger als 15 Nukleotide sind, kodiert werden zur Verwendung in einem Verfahren zur Behandlung einer Krankheit, die durch erhöhte Apoptose, Wachstumsverzögerung oder verlangsamte Wundheilung charakterisiert ist, durch Aktivieren des Fortschreitens des Zellzyklus.

Verwendung eines isolierten Nukleinsäuremoleküls umfassend eine wie in Anspruch 1 bis 6 definierte Sequenz oder Verwendung eines Antikörpers wie in Anspruch 7 definiert, für die in-vitro Diagnose einer proliferativen Erkrankung oder einer Erkrankung, die mit abnormalem Fortschreiten des Zellzyklus verbunden ist, insbesondere wobei die Krankheit koronare Restenose oder eine neoplastische Erkrankung ist, wobei die letztere vorzugsweise ausgewählt ist aus der Gruppe bestehend aus Lymphom, Lungenkrebs, Kolonkrebs, Eierstockkrebs und Brustkrebs.

Diagnostischer Kit enthaltend ein isoliertes Nukleinsäuremolekül wie in Anspruch 1 oder 2 definiert und/oder einen Antikörper wie in Anspruch 7 definiert für die in-vitro Diagnose einer proliferativen Erkrankung oder einer Erkrankung, die mit abnormalem Fortschreiten des Zellzyklus verbunden ist.

Verwendung eines isolierten Nukleinsäuremoleküls oder eines Nukleinsäure-Expressionsvektors wie in einem beliebigen der Ansprüche 1 bis 6 definiert oder eines Polypeptids mit einer Sequenz wie in Anspruch 7 definiert oder eines Antikörpers wie in Anspruch 7 definiert, in einem Screeningtest zur Identifikation und Charakterisierung von Wirkstoffen, die das Fortschreiten des Zellzyklus inhibieren oder aktivieren.

Screeningverfahren zur Identifikation und Charakterisierung eines Inhibitor- oder eines Aktivatormoleküls, das das Fortschreiten des Zellzyklus inhibiert oder aktiviert, umfassend die folgenden Schritte: a) Transformieren eines wie in Anspruch 9 definierten Nukleinsäuremoleküls in eine Wirtszelle oder einen nicht-menschlichen Wirtsorganismus, b) Kultivieren der Wirtszelle oder des Wirtsorganismus, die/der in Schritt a) erhalten wurde, unter Bedingungen, die die Überexpression des Polypeptids oder der RNA, die von der Nukleinsäure aus Schritt a) kodiert wird oder dieser entspricht, erlauben, entweder in Gegenwart oder in Abwesenheit von mindestens einem Kandidaten für ein Inhibitor- oder Aktivatormolekül, und c) Analyse des Fortschreitens des Zellzyklus in der kultivierten Zelle oder dem kultivierten Organismus und hierdurch Identifizieren eines Inhibitors oder Aktivators des Fortschreitens des Zellzyklus.

Screeningverfahren zur Identifikation und Charakterisierung eines wechselwirkenden Moleküls, das das Fortschreiten des Zellzyklus inhibiert oder aktiviert, aus einer Bibliothek von Testsubstanzen umfassend die folgenden Schritte: a) rekombinantes Exprimieren eines Polypeptids, das von einer Nukleinsäuremolekülsequenz wie in Anspruch 9 definiert, kodiert wird, in einer Wirtszelle, b) Isolieren und gegebenenfalls Reinigen des rekombinant exprimierten Polypeptids aus Schritt a), c) gegebenenfalls Markieren der Testsubstanzen und/oder Markieren des rekombinant exprimierten Polypeptids, d) Immobilisieren des rekombinant exprimierten Polypeptids an eine feste Phase, e) Inkontaktbringen mindestens einer Testsubstanz mit dem immobilisierten Polypeptid, f) gegebenenfalls ein oder mehrere Waschschritte, g) Nachweisen der Bindung der mindestens einen Testsubstanz an das an der festen Phase immobilisierte Polypeptid und h) Durchführen eines funktionellen Tests zur Inhibierung oder Aktivierung des Fortschreitens des Zellzyklus.

An isolated nucleic acid molecule comprising a nucleic acid molecule with a sequence selected from the group of sequences consisting of: a) sequences of nucleic acid molecules which are capable of hybridizing under conditions of medium or high stringency with - the nucleic acid molecules with sequences presented in SEQ ID NO. 1, 3, or - nucleic acid sequences encoding polypeptides that exhibit a sequence identity with the protein encoded by a nucleic acid according to SEQ ID NO. 1 or 3 of at least 70 % over 100 residues and/or which are detectable in a computer aided search using the BLAST sequence analysis programs with an e-value of at most 10-5, b) the antisense-sequence of any of the sequences as defined in SEQ ID NO. 1, 3, or the antisense-sequence of any of the nucleic acid sequences encoding polypeptides that exhibit a sequence identity with the protein encoded by a nucleic acid according to SEQ ID NO. 1 or 3 of at least 70 % over 100 residues and/or which are detectable in a computer aided search using the BLAST sequence analysis programs with an e-value of at most 10-5, c) fragments of (a) or (b), wherein the fragments are larger than 15 nucleotides, d) single-stranded RNA in the antisense direction corresponding to any of the sequences as defined in SEQ ID NO. 1, 3 or corresponding to any of the nucleic acid sequences encoding polypeptides that exhibit a sequence identity with the protein encoded by a nucleic acid according to SEQ ID NO. 1 or 3 of at least 70 % over 100 residues and/or which are detectable in a computer aided search using the BLAST sequence analysis programs with an e-value of at most 10-5, or single-stranded RNA in the sense direction corresponding to any of the sequences as defined in (a) for use in a method of therapy of a proliferative disease by inhibiting cell cycle progression.

The nucleic acid molecule for use according to claim 1, wherein the isolated nucleic acid molecule comprises small interfering RNA with a sequence corresponding to any of the sequences according to claim 1, or wherein the nucleic acid molecule is contained in at least one nucleic acid expression vector which is capable of producing a double-stranded RNA-molecule comprising a sense-RNA-stand and an antisense-RNA-strand under suitable conditions, wherein each RNA-strand, independently from the other, has a length of 19 to 31 nucleotides.

The nucleic acid molecule for use according to claim 1, wherein the nucleic acid molecule is contained in at least one nucleic acid expression vector comprising a first expression cassette containing the nucleic acid corresponding to the sense-RNA-strand under the control of a first promoter and a second expression cassette containing the nucleic acid corresponding to the antisense-RNA-strand under the control of a second promoter.

The nucleic acid molecule for use according to claim 1, wherein the nucleic acid molecule is contained in at least one nucleic acid expression vector comprising an expression cassette containing the nucleic acid corresponding to the sense-RNA-strand and the antisense-RNA-strand under the control of a promoter leading to a single-stranded RNA-molecule and wherein the single-stranded RNA-molecule is capable of forming a back-folded stem-loop-structure.
The nucleic acid molecule for use according to any of claims 2 to 4, wherein each RNA-strand, independently from the other, has a length of 20 to 25, preferably of 20 to 22 nucleotides.
The nucleic acid molecule for use according to any of claims 2 to 4, wherein each RNA-strand, independently from the other, has a length of 26 to 28, preferably of 27 nucleotides.

An antibody which is directed against at least one peptide or polypeptide with a sequence selected from the group consisting of: (a) a sequence as disclosed in SEQ ID NO. 2, 4; (b) a sequence that exhibits a sequence identity with any of the sequences according to (a) of at least 70 % over 100 residues, (c) fragments of the sequences defined in (a) or (b), wherein the fragments are encoded by fragments of the nucleic acid sequences larger than 15 nucleotides for use in a method of therapy of a proliferative disease by inhibiting cell cycle progression.

The nucleic acid molecule for use according to any of claims I to 6 or the antibody for use according to claim 7, wherein the disease is coronary restenosis or a neoplastic disease, the latter preferably selected from the group consisting of lymphoma, lung cancer, colon cancer, ovarian cancer and breast cancer.

A medicament comprising an isolated nucleic acid molecule comprising a nucleic acid with a sequence selected from the group of sequences consisting of: a) the nucleic acid sequences presented in SEQ ID NO. 1, 3; b) nucleic acid sequences encoding polypeptides that exhibit a sequence identity with the protein encoded by a nucleic acid according to a) of at least 70 % over 100 residues and/or which are detectable in a computer aided search using the BLAST sequence analysis programs with an e-value of at most 10-5, c) fragments of (a) or (b), wherein the fragments are larger than 15 nucleotides, or an isolated peptide or polypeptide comprising a peptide or polypeptide with a sequence selected from the group consisting of: d) a sequence as disclosed in SEQ ID NO. 2, 4; e) a sequence that exhibits a sequence identity with any of the sequences according to (d) of at least 70 % over 100 residues, f) fragments of the sequences defined in (d) or (e), wherein the fragments are encoded by fragments of the nucleic acid sequences larger than 15 nucleotides for use in a method of treatment of a disease characterized by increased apoptosis, growth retardation, or slowed wound healing, by activating cell cycle progression.

The use of an isolated nucleic acid molecule comprising a sequence as defined in claim 1 to 6 or the use of an antibody as defined in claim 7 for the in vitro diagnosis of a proliferative disease or a disease associated with abnormal cell cycle progression, particularly wherein the disease is coronary restenosis or a neoplastic disease, the latter preferably selected from the group consisting of lymphoma, lung cancer, colon cancer, ovarian cancer and breast cancer.

A diagnostic kit containing an isolated nucleic acid molecule as defined in claim 1 or 2 and/or an antibody as defined in claim 7 for the in vitro diagnosis of a proliferative disease or a disease associated with abnormal cell cycle progression.

The use of an isolated nucleic acid molecule or of a nucleic acid expression vectors as defined in any of claims 1 to 6 or of a polypeptide with a sequence as defined in claim 7 or of an antibody as defined in claim 7, in a screening assay for the identification and characterization of drugs that inhibit or activate cell cycle progression.

A screening method for the identification and characterization of an inhibitor or an activator molecule that inhibits or activates cell cycle progression comprising the following steps: a) transformation of a nucleic acid molecule as defined in claim9 into a host cell or a non-human host organism, b) cultivation of the host cell or host organism obtained in step a) under conditions that allow the overexpression of the polypeptide or RNA encoded by or corresponding to the nucleic acid of step a) either in the presence or in the absence of at least one candidate for an inhibitor- or activator-molecule, and c) analysis of the cell cycle progression in the cultivated cell or organism and thereby identification of an inhibitor or activator of cell cycle progression.

A screening method for the identification and characterization of an interacting molecule that inhibits or activates cell cycle progression from a library of test substances comprising the following steps: a) recombinantly expressing a polypeptide encoded by a nucleic acid molecule sequence as defined in claim 9 in a host cell, b) isolating and optionally purifying the recombinantly expressed polypeptide of step (a), c) optionally labelling of the test substances and/or labelling of the recombinantly expressed polypeptide, d) immobilizing the recombinantly expressed polypeptide to a solid phase, e) contacting of at least one test substance with the immobilized polypeptide, f) optionally one or more washing steps, g) detecting the binding of the at least one test substance to the immobilized polypeptid at the solid phase, and h) performing a functional assay for inhibition or activation of cell cycle progression.

Molécule d'acides nucléiques isolée comprenant une molécule d'acides nucléiques ayant une séquence choisie dans le groupe de séquences constitué par : a) des séquences de molécules d'acides nucléiques qui sont capables de s'hybrider dans des conditions de stringence moyenne ou élevée avec - les molécules d'acides nucléiques ayant les séquences présentées en SEQ ID NO. 1, 3, ou - des séquences d'acides nucléiques codant des polypeptides qui présentent une identité de séquence avec la protéine codée par un acide nucléique selon SEQ ID NO. 1 ou 3 d'au moins 70 % sur 100 résidus et/ou qui sont détectables lors d'une recherche informatisée au moyen des programmes d'analyse de séquences BLAST avec une valeur e d'au plus 10-5, b) la séquence antisens de l'une quelconque des séquences définies en SEQ ID NO. 1, 3, ou la séquence antisens de l'une quelconque des séquences d'acides nucléiques codant des polypeptides qui présentent une identité de séquence avec la protéine codée par un acide nucléique selon SEQ ID NO. 1 ou 3 d'au moins 70 % sur 100 résidus et/ou qui sont détectables lors d'une recherche informatisée au moyen des programmes d'analyse de séquences BLAST avec une valeur e d'au plus 10-5, c) des fragments de (a) ou (b), dans lesquels les fragments sont plus longs que 15 nucléotides, d) un ARN simple-brin dans la direction antisens correspondant à l'une quelconque des séquences définies en SEQ ID NO. 1, 3 ou correspondant à l'une quelconque des séquences d'acides nucléiques codant des polypeptides qui présentent une identité de séquence avec la protéine codée par un acide nucléique selon SEQ ID NO. 1 ou 3 d'au moins 70 % sur 100 résidus et/ou qui sont détectables lors d'une recherche informatisée au moyen des programmes d'analyse de séquences BLAST avec une valeur e d'au plus 10-5, ou un ARN simple-brin dans la direction sens correspondant à l'une quelconque des séquences définies en (a), pour son utilisation dans un procédé de traitement d'une maladie proliférative par l'inhibition de la progression du cycle cellulaire.

Molécule d'acides nucléiques pour son utilisation selon la revendication 1, dans laquelle la molécule d'acides nucléiques isolée comprend un petit ARN interférent ayant une séquence correspondant à l'une quelconque des séquences selon la revendication 1, ou dans laquelle la molécule d'acides nucléiques est contenue dans au moins un vecteur d'expression d'acide nucléique qui est capable de produire une molécule d'ARN double-brin comprenant un brin d'ARN sens et un brin d'ARN antisens dans des conditions appropriées, dans laquelle chaque brin d'ARN, indépendamment l'un de l'autre, a une longueur de 19 à 31 nucléotides.

Molécule d'acides nucléiques pour son utilisation selon la revendication 1, dans laquelle la molécule d'acides nucléiques est contenue dans au moins un vecteur d'expression d'acide nucléique comprenant une première cassette d'expression contenant l'acide nucléique correspondant au brin d'ARN sens sous le contrôle d'un premier promoteur et une seconde cassette d'expression contenant l'acide nucléique correspondant au brin d'ARN antisens sous le contrôle d'un second promoteur.

Molécule d'acides nucléiques pour son utilisation selon la revendication 1, dans laquelle la molécule d'acides nucléiques est contenue dans au moins un vecteur d'expression d'acide nucléique comprenant une cassette d'expression contenant l'acide nucléique correspondant au brin d'ARN sens et au brin d'ARN antisens sous le contrôle d'un promoteur donnant une molécule d'ARN simple-brin et dans laquelle la molécule d'ARN simple-brin est capable de former une structure tige-boucle repliée.

Molécule d'acides nucléiques pour son utilisation selon l'une quelconque des revendications 2 à 4, dans laquelle chaque brin d'ARN, indépendamment l'un de l'autre, a une longueur de 20 à 25 nucléotides, de préférence de 20 à 22 nucléotides.

Molécule d'acides nucléiques pour son utilisation selon l'une quelconque des revendications 2 à 4, dans laquelle chaque brin d'ARN, indépendamment l'un de l'autre, a une longueur de 26 à 28 nucléotides, de préférence de 27 nucléotides.

Anticorps qui est dirigé contre au moins un peptide ou polypeptide ayant une séquence choisie dans le groupe constitué par : (a) une séquence telle que décrite en SEQ ID NO. 2, 4 ; (b) une séquence qui présente une identité de séquence avec l'une quelconque des séquences selon (a) d'au moins 70 % sur 100 résidus, (c) des fragments des séquences définies en (a) et (b), dans lesquels les fragments sont codés par des fragments des séquences d'acides nucléiques plus longs que 15 nucléotides, pour son utilisation dans un procédé de traitement d'une maladie proliférative par l'inhibition de la progression du cycle cellulaire.

Molécule d'acides nucléiques pour son utilisation selon l'une quelconque des revendications 1 à 6 ou anticorps pour son utilisation selon la revendication 7, dans laquelle la maladie est la resténose coronaire ou une maladie néoplasique, cette dernière étant choisie de préférence dans le groupe constitué des lymphomes, du cancer du poumon, du cancer du côlon, du cancer des ovaires et du cancer du sein.

Médicament comprenant une molécule d'acides nucléiques isolée comprenant un acide nucléique ayant une séquence choisie dans le groupe de séquences constitué par : a) les séquences d'acides nucléiques présentées en SEQ ID NO. 1, 3 ; b) des séquences d'acides nucléiques codant des polypeptides qui présentent une identité de séquence avec la protéine codée par un acide nucléique selon a) d'au moins 70 % sur 100 résidus et/ou qui sont détectables lors d'une recherche informatisée au moyen des programmes d'analyse de séquences BLAST avec une valeur e d'au plus 10-5, c) des fragments de (a) ou (b), dans lesquels les fragments sont plus longs que 15 nucléotides, ou un peptide ou polypeptide isolé comprenant un peptide ou polypeptide ayant une séquence choisie dans le groupe constitué par : d) une séquence telle que décrite en SEQ ID NO. 2, 4 ; e) une séquence qui présente une identité de séquence avec l'une quelconque des séquences selon (d) d'au moins 70 % sur 100 résidus, f) des fragments des séquences définies dans (d) ou (e), dans lesquels les fragments sont codés par des fragments des séquences d'acides nucléiques plus longs que 15 nucléotides, pour son utilisation dans un procédé de traitement d'une maladie caractérisée par une apoptose accrue, un retard de croissance ou un ralentissement de la cicatrisation, par l'activation de la progression du cycle cellulaire.

Utilisation d'une molécule d'acides nucléiques isolée comprenant une séquence telle que définie dans les revendications 1 à 6 ou utilisation d'un anticorps tel que défini dans la revendication 7, pour le diagnostic in vitro d'une maladie proliférative ou d'une maladie associée à une progression anormale du cycle cellulaire, en particulier dans laquelle la maladie est la resténose coronaire ou une maladie néoplasique, cette dernière étant choisie de préférence dans le groupe constitué des lymphomes, du cancer du poumon, du cancer du côlon, du cancer des ovaires et du cancer du sein.

Kit de diagnostic contenant une molécule d'acides nucléiques isolée telle que définie dans la revendication 1 ou 2 et/ou un anticorps tel que défini dans la revendication 7, pour le diagnostic in vitro d'une maladie proliférative ou d'une maladie associée à une progression anormale du cycle cellulaire.

Utilisation d'une molécule d'acides nucléiques isolée ou d'un vecteur d'expression d'acide nucléique tel que défini dans l'une quelconque des revendications 1 à 6 ou d'un polypeptide ayant une séquence telle que définie dans la revendication 7 ou d'un anticorps tel que défini dans la revendication 7, dans un test de criblage pour identifier et caractériser des médicaments qui inhibent ou activent la progression du cycle cellulaire.

Procédé de criblage pour identifier et caractériser une molécule inhibitrice ou une molécule activatrice qui inhibe ou active la progression du cycle cellulaire, comprenant les étapes suivantes : a) la transformation d'une molécule d'acides nucléiques telle que définie dans la revendication 9 dans une cellule hôte ou dans un organisme hôte non humain, b) la culture de la cellule hôte ou de l'organisme hôte obtenu dans l'étape a) dans des conditions permettant la surexpression du polypeptide ou de l'ARN codé par ou correspondant à l'acide nucléique de l'étape a), en présence ou en l'absence d'au moins un candidat pour une molécule inhibitrice ou activatrice, et c) l'analyse de la progression du cycle cellulaire dans la cellule cultivée ou l'organisme, pour ainsi identifier un inhibiteur ou un activateur de la progression du cycle cellulaire.

Procédé de criblage pour identifier et caractériser une molécule d'interaction qui inhibe ou active la progression du cycle cellulaire provenant d'une banque de substances à tester, comprenant les étapes suivantes : a) l'expression par recombinaison d'un polypeptide codé par une séquence de molécule d'acide nucléique telle que définie dans la revendication 9 dans une cellule hôte, b) l'isolement et éventuellement la purification du polypeptide exprimé par recombinaison dans l'étape a), c) éventuellement le marquage des substances à tester et/ou le marquage du polypeptide exprimé par recombinaison, d) l'immobilisation du polypeptide exprimé par recombinaison sur un support solide, e) la mise en contact d'au moins une substance à tester avec le polypeptide immobilisé, f) éventuellement une ou plusieurs étapes de lavage, g) la détection de la liaison de l'au moins une substance à tester au polypeptide immobilisé sur la phase solide, et h) la mise en oeuvre d'un test fonctionnel pour déterminer l'inhibition ou l'activation de la progression du cycle cellulaire.
